Comment: On one particular point, I think the authors exaggerate the downside of implementing a carbon tax. They claim that it will drive businesses away from whatever jurisdiction implements the tax, and cite as examples, agriculture and resources. 
Well, I'm pretty sure that farmers are not going to move their land, mining companies are not going to move their mines and forestry companies are not going to move their forests. What those companies should do is reduce the amount of fossil fuels that they use, and find ways of producing a lower carbon product like the rest of the world does. 
Are carbon taxes the only instrument that we should be using to prevent catastrophic global warming? No, but they help. It's a lot like taxes on cigarettes. Do taxes make everyone quit? No. But along with education and social pressure, they help.

Comment: What a ridiculous, hyperbolic, irresponsible article. Here's the real story on the ground in Vancouver, from the perspective of my fiancee and I who have been looking for a modest East side home for about two years:

Prices have not come down at the lower end of the market (read: entry level houses at $1.3-1.7 million), and there are very few good listings which would explain the drop in sales (not prices). Sometime around last summer, list prices caught up to the real sale prices, so the places that sell now are actually going for asking, or slightly below, however the sale prices still show a stable or even slight upward trend and the market is only "balanced" in the sense that now you might actually have a chance to make a slightly lower offer and/or have time to do a home inspection instead of just losing a bidding war. Prices are still about 40% higher than they were two years ago.

This is not the sound of a bubble burstin, but if it were, it would be good news to most people.

Comment: thanks for posting her reply to me.  I hadn't seen it.  I highly appreciate her statement, "...I support a system that provides the most extensive health care for all at the lowest cost." 

 That is HR676 Medicare For All.  

One item in her statement needs clarifying:  the state of Hawaii doesn't need to approve congress's bill, so, Hawaii's need for an ERISA exemption is only relevant for a state passed bill.  If congress passes a bill, a state will not need to get federal approval in order to follow that law.

The ERISA exemption is relevant if we talk about the Hawaii Health Authority HRS 322, which is a law passed in 2009 which states that Hawaii will create Universal Health Care Plan. 

BTW, MFA would accomplish the goals of the pre paid health care act, which is coverage, but, it accomplishs the goal at a much, much, much lower cost.  the PPHC Act would need to be repealed, if HR676 is passed, because obviously health insurance would be separated from employment.

- Generally, there is an effort not to disregard canon law as it applies to parishes, in such dioceses the bishop or  staff will trump canon law with civil law in dealing with parish property, especially after a parish is dissolved.

Comment: Apologies Leah, but this piece is bad, from a science reporting perspective. Even if these studies' methodologies hold up (I have no idea), the explanations given for causation range from speculative to nonsensical. For instance: you talk about how Dads take a less small share of the parenting responsibilities than they used to, but there is nothing about change over time in the study results. Are you suggesting that Dads today have more influence on their childrens' weight than they did in the past? Because that is entirely unsupported.

Also, the "staggering 10 times" figure that you cite has no real relevance, which you even implicitly acknowledge when you mention the 'obese Dad' vs 'obese Mom' results. But then for some reason you don't actually give the real number, instead simply saying they "did not have the same outcomes."

Come on, readers can handle objective analysis, and we don't need speculation and hyperbole for a health article to be interesting.

Comment: Who's more likely and has more incentive to sell pot to kids: criminals on the black market or a heavily regulated industry?

Your experience might be different, but when I was growing up it was a lot easier to get pot than it was to get alcohol or cigarettes. 

These ideas that legalization and regulation somehow leads to MORE crime and MORE abuse by children is completely unfounded. It is precisely these reasons that I want to see it legalized and regulated. I'd rather isolate the problem to a few people who abuse it rather than throw in danger to children, black market crime, and gangs. I'd like to see the police focusing on bigger issues. Pot, compared to hard drugs, is minor - not to mention how much better it is for pain management and a variety of other uses.

If my father didn't have pot to manage his pain he'd go back to opioids and die. I'd rather see adults use it recreationally over children. I know you mean well, but I don't agree with your approach. Keep an open mind.

Comment: No trainer, private, LEO, or military, teaches to "shoot to maim." You shoot to -stop- at center mass, where you have the likeliest chance of actually hitting your attacker and doing immediately incapacitating damage. If the person ends up dying that is an unfortunate side effect.  

Aside from the extremities being harder to hit, and a miss doesn't stop an attacker, they are also more likely to allow a shot to pass through and endanger others further downrange.  The irony of shooting extremities is that hits will not reliably stop an attacker but can potentially kill them later. There are no safe places to shoot at someone to "wound," too many large blood vessels can be damaged that can end up killing. It's also potentially a way to end up in jail. Lethal force, using a gun, is only justified by a lethal force threat. By shooting to wound you are implicitly stating the threat wasn't life-threatening, making your use of lethal force in response viewable as criminally disproportionate.

Comment: So much to comment on...

It is not uncommon under ACMPR licenses to yield a pound (455g) per plant in about 5 months.  But, some people prefer to grow 10 plants in a single meter using an SOG system with a lower yield.  So, the 4-plant, 1-meter high restriction is extremely arbitrary.   

No allowance is made for the fact that young plants, or male plants, do not produce cannabis flowers or resin of any useful quantity.  Plants grown from regular seeds will be 50% male on average.  

The 'maximum' for home growing should be related to area in square meters, not number of plants. 

The proposed law allows for medical growing under ACMPR.  In addition to the 4-plant legal limit per home, ACMPR personal production licenses are valid so, in addition to the 4-plants, up to 4 people per household holding personal grow licenses under ACMPR and could potentially grow an additional 100 plants in a home.  This yields a theoretical maximum total per household of 104 cannabis plants.

Comment: Several reasons. Border officers have a legal power to refuse entry and direct persons back that inland officers do not possess.

Also once a person is physically within Canada, Charter rights are engaged and there is a right to have eligibility for a refugee claim assessed and then a hearing before an independent tribunal (the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board).

Back in 1985 the SCOC determined that the lack of an oral hearing for a refugee claimant before an independent tribunal was unconstitutional Singh v Canada (Minister of Employment and Immigration), [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177.  Singh determined that any person in Canada even without legal status was protected by the Charter.  That decision was based on section 7 rights to security of person and fundamental justice.

Comment: Joni Kamiya, You are going way off topic, talking about lead exposure and rat lungworm disease.  Chlorpyrifos is one of the most widely used pesticides in the world.  Indoor use of chlorpyrifos was phased out starting in 2000 because of potential health concerns, and is now permitted only in child-resistant ant and roach baits.

The EPA recently refused to ban chlorpyrifos, despite its own analysis which concluded that children were being exposed to up to 140 times the safe levels of the pesticide through food alone. An earlier report said drinking water can also be contaminated.  Studies on pregnant women and children done at Columbia University that found evidence of neurodevelopmental effects in children whose mothers were exposed to chlorpyrifos in pregnancy.

Pesticide companies were successful in stopping SB 804 because they were concerned about maintaining profitability, not about the health of people.

Comment: A bike tax is an interesting proposition. Many motorists believe cyclists should pay their fair share for use of roads. What would the tax look like?
To estimate revenue, assume a cyclist rides on average 1500 miles a year. At the current gas tax a car getting 25 mpg pays about 1.2 cents per mile. Do we tax at the mpg rate for bikes which get a 700 mpg equivalent?
Let's just tax at the 1.2 rate motorists pay. That 1500 miles a year generates $18 per cyclist. Round that up to a $20 yearly fee. 
How many cyclists are there? Do we charge a fee for every bike? A family of 4 who ride on occasion would pay $100 a year. How about transients? Do we confiscate their bikes if they don't pay the fee?
If we assume there are 20,000 active cyclists in the state that would pay the $20 fee, this raises $400,000 annually. 
$400,000 of $1.3 billion is .0003% toward roads, minus an admin fee. 
How do we enforce the law?

Comment: "So, Eastern Canada shall continue to get its oil products from Saudi Arabia"

Not so. Most heavy oil for refining in St. John comes from Venezuela. Energy East would have substituted heavy oil from Alberta.

Saudi oil is generally light - the light oil that is blended in St. John with the Orinoco heavy grades is mostly sourced from the Bakken in North Dakota.

The fact is that for Energy East to be economically-feasible, it requires exports of oil from St. John and also Quebec. This is the rub - I'm all for energy self-sufficiency, but exporting oil is another thing entirely.

Comment: "Diversity is our strength. Is there any actual evidence of this?"

Yes there is. Hundreds of millions of years of evidence. Diversity provides any given population of organisms with the ability to withstand the forces that might act against it. Here's a simple and modern example.

Within a population of bacteria, some bacteria will be resistant to antibiotics. They survive the treatments we apply, and then multiply. Their offspring have the same immunity. That group of bacteria then thrives despite the forces that are acting against it.

In a nutshell, that's the advantage of diversity. It provides a population with resilience against external threats.

Comment: It seems most of the commenters thus far don’t put a lot of stock in satisfied employees.  I would be willing to bet that few of them have progressed past middle management, or perhaps they haven’t much experience in highly skilled environments.

If the only reason workers are showing up is for a paycheck, their sole motivation will be not getting fired.  Hardly the dynamic workforce a business needs to succeed.  Dictatorial bosses will always gain respect……but never to their back.

I have managed in both low skill environments (restaurants) and incredibly specialized and skilled ones (high tech).  Very early in my management career, I discovered that happy employees mean high productivity – and incredible loyalty and effort during crunch times.  It doesn’t take that much – pay them a fair wage, compensate for overtime, and recognize good work frequently.  Be understanding when they have a personal crisis.  It isn’t rocket science.

Comment: Again, you're looking at superficial factors. Poverty and drug use correlate to crime, they do not cause it. There are reams of data on the subject, the vast majority of the poor or un/under-educated in any given location are neither violent criminals nor drug users. Instead, both groups form a distinct interconnected minority within the larger set "the poor."

When we talk about social and cultural factors we're talking about long-term factors that remain in play even through economic changes. For example, one key cultural factor that strongly correlates to violent crime across societies is heterogeneity. Homogenous societies, societies made up of one distinct group with largely uniform beliefs, a mono-culture, tend to have less conflict and less violent crime, regardless of the national GDP.  Societies that are more diverse, where different cultural belief systems interact, tend to have more violent crime. Thus the consistent differences in rates between the US and, say, Europe.

Comment: With GHGs, there are “bites” taken out of that curve where individual GHGs are absorbing and attenuating outgoing radiation. The area under the curve is now less than 240. The Earth must warm to push the curve “higher” to get the area under that curve back to 240. The combined bites and resulting warming increase the surface temperature to 288 K (15ºC). That 33 K warming is the result of the GHE. Now you can get a clear idea of each GHG’s effect by looking at its bite out of the Planck curve. The two that seem appropriate to this conversation are CO₂ and WV. WV absorbs at many different wavelengths, but not especially strongly. You can see this as all of the jagged, but not deep, bites over most of the curve. In contrast, the very large bite at 15 µm is from CO₂. Again, any bite out of the curve increases GMST. This should give you an idea of CO₂'s impact.

https://wattsupwiththat.files.wordpress.com/2011/03/gw-petty-6-6.jpg

Comment: "If they have their way, what is to become of faithful Catholics, who" think that sexism is just peaching-keen? Because that is the actual reason for not ordaining women. They used to be open about it. For example, Thomas Aquinas, in the Summa Theologica Supplement, q 39 art 1 considers the question, "Whether the female sex is an impediment to receiving Orders?". He says that it is, for two reasons. The first is that women are inferior to men: "since it is not possible in the female sex to signify eminence of degree, for a woman is in the state of subjection, it follows that she cannot receive the sacrament of Orders". (The second reason is that the tonsure is not appropriate for women.)

Now, they try to pretty it up with words like "complementarity" and "ontological differences", but "inferior" is what they really mean.

Comment: The promise to change the electoral process before the next election was politically expedient - and stupid.

The issue of electoral reform is important - but the Liberals did not have a mandate to implement changes to the system before the next election.

This does not mean they should stop doing analysis.

What they should do -- is research options, provide cost / benefit analysis; and launch an education campaign.

Then during the next election there should be a 2 part referendum question on the ballot:
 (a)  do you support changing the system from first past the post (current method)

 and 
(b) which option would you prefer?

In order for the referendum to pass -- there must be a majority (and perhaps a super-majority) in favour of changing the system.
If the answer to the first question is yes -- the largest % of the votes for option (b) would determine the electoral system to change to.

-
Other questions (such as changes to voting age) would be up to future governments

-

Comment: Early in the evening the deputy marshal, dressed in citizen's clothing, called to see me with an apparently friendly message from the Queen's Marshall, Charles B. Wilson, but obviously to finf out the disposition of our forces, and the part we proposed to take in the event of a fight.  I understood his mission and extended to him a most cordial reception, took him all around the camp and emphatically informed him we were there simply to protect American life and property, and under no circumstances would we take part with either side.  He replied he knew that , and the next evening the Marshall Wilson told me he knew we would have nothing to do with either side, and wanted to go out and fight but wasn't allowed to.  The deputy departed with a friendly message and cordial feelings, and offered to send me something for my comfort in camp, which he did later that night.
So, if the Queen did not want them there, her operatives had a funny way of showing it!

Comment: Tom, 

This is about giving control back to the state Fish & Game Department control over federal public property. It is the state that employs the "intensive predator management" policy, which allows shooting wolf and other predators from aircraft by civilians. But the main point is that the department uses its employees to essentially exterminate what it perceives as excessive amounts of predators by all sorts of methods including using aircraft, gassing pups and bear cubs in their dens, placing tracking collars on individual wolves so that they may be tracked back to the pack, whereby the entire family can be killed. This is all public record and official policy. The Feds were essentially forced to step in to stop this obnoxious nonsense because it is so outrageous and against every value that ethical management agencies stand for. So, if the state would drop this wholly obnoxious policy the Feds wouldn't need to be involved. Until then someone needs to be a voice of reason.

Comment: After having started several companies that successfully attracted substantial venture funding and ultimately sold to large international corporations, I have to comment that creating a start-up company is straightforward provided that one has a sales ready product wanted by a substantial market.  At Universities there is typically great confusion between ideas and products.  An idea that will take years of research to reduce to practice is not a good basis for a company.  In fact, if there is any research at all left, it is likely that a company venture funded to sell potential product will fail.  Some start companies by selling the idea for a product.  If they are smart they can make a bundle from investors before the company fails as investors often cannot tell how far an idea is from being reduced to practice.  It is best start business only when the idea has already been reduced to practice and is ready to sell.

Comment: Arsenic in North American grown rice has been made worse than it otherwise would be because arsenic was used extensively for 100 years+ as a pesticide to combat the boll weevil in cotton plantations. As a result, large amounts of pesticide-arsenic have accumulated in soils in southern states where cotton was grown. Much  former cotton growing land is now used to grow rice. Most supposedly healthy brown rice is grown in southern states and thus is likely to have high arsenic content. Brown rice grown in California is safer as there's no California history of arsenic use as an agricultural pesticide and no arsenic accumulation in soils there. 

But I've had problems finding rice I could be sure was grown in Calif. Even if the distributing company's listed as located in  Calif. that doesn't necessarily mean the rice was grown there. And I can't find brown rice at a reasonable price grown outside North America. So, I've given up "healthier" brown rice, and switched to Indian
white basmati.

Comment: I have another factor for whatever levels of anxiety we suffer today (more than previous generations?  I'll debate that!): 

Instantaneous 24/7 extensive news coverage on TV, available on computers.  Tough to avoid. I think there's something to the old saying, "Ignorance is bliss."  Back less than 100 years ago, there was no (1) radio (2) TV and (3) most people didn't subscribe to newspapers nor did they buy them at all. If they did, most of them--because most people lived quiet, rural small-town lives-- likely purchased the local "rag" which didn't feature much in the way of national, international or even regional news.  They remained pretty ignorant of all sorts of catastrophes. It took a day or two before somebody in small-town Texas to hear about Lincoln's assassinations...unless they heard "rumours" of it. By then it was history.

Comment: While terminating the 'income sprinkling' benefit enjoyed by doctors and dentists has some merit on the fairness account, it is the attack on private corporation investment arrangements that is completely unfair and that should light a fire under Conservative Party fund-raising.

Employees with pension plans get to save money for retirement in in a 100% tax-deferred bubble.  Private corporation owners currently get to save money in a partially tax deferred bubble, and it is that partial deferral that the Liberal government is attacking.

What the government needs to recognize is that many IT and health professionals have skills that are mobile, and that can disappear abroad when the tax regime specifically targets them for punishment as part of a political strategy to appease the school teachers and other government employees the Liberal government is banking on for political survival.

Without a robust private sector, there is no public sector.  The Venezuela North push needs to stop.

Comment: The state of civics education in Canada is appalling. Many fail to understand the role of  the judiciary. - although I am sure a good deal of this misunderstanding is rhetoric.

When governments make bad laws, and citizens challenge these laws, and these challenges make their way all the way up to the Supreme Court, *then* the Judges make a ruling. If governments didn't make laws of political convenience then judges wouldn't strike them down. When governments fail to act at all - because the decision would alienate too many voters and citizens make a legal challenge, the courts have no choice but to rule on existing legislation.  

If you don't want or like "activist judges" insist your elected representatives do their jobs and do their jobs well. When they don't, toss them from office.  We don't need hastily created frivolous laws, and we don't need laws of political expediency. The Harper government created a lot to show they were "tough on crime", this is the result we get.

Comment: This isn't great news to the families still left in the community. At the same time, however, Alaskans need to seriously reflect on the sustainability of many of our rural villages and the services that we as a society are asked (or legally mandated) to provide. As an example, spending $100MM for a new school for Kivilina, including all of the costs of administering and maintaining it, strikes me as an egregious example of the type of spending that will continue to keep our state's education funding at unsustainable levels.

It's also debatable whether having a small school in a village provides the type of education that helps students succeed. Many village schools don't offer higher-level math or science, art, music, and many other courses to which a student in Fairbanks, Anchorage, etc., would have access. We need to think about other options instead of blindly throwing more money at the problem.

Comment: Telling women to have fewer children will not cure overpopulation.

Comment: Excellent column. Last month, I was in Toronto and desperately needed to go. I saw a museum/theme house and assumed it would have a public toilet. The guide who greeted me indicated there was not one available. Thinking this was a matter of being a paying customer, I offered to make a donation. There still was no toilet available, a point impressed upon me by the manager, who directed me to a nearby Starbucks (which I had not known was there). I told her I was not sure I could make it to the Starbucks, but that did not sway her. Thankfully, I made it to the Starbucks and, though I had to wait in line for five minutes, the fact that I was no longer moving made it possible for me to hold it in. While I waited, I had a conversation with a lady in line about how ridiculous and potentially disastrous the lack of access to public toilets can be. This is a major public health issue. Our cities should be acting on this now.

Comment: People are less apathetic there than here. Still, the fractured nature of political parties in the Netherlands (there are 20 on the ballot, and none gets more than about 20% support) means that governing is very difficult, and only the safest policies are adopted, because they need to be approved by the four or five parties of the coalition. In the Canadian system, there are huge waves from election to election, and the winning party has a mandate for four years. This party can actually do whatever it wants- it only has to answer to the people after that time. An individual vote means less, but collectively it means more. As it should; ours is a better system imho.

Comment: Yes we do - but we need to do so in a well planned manner that minimizes waste and maximizes performance.  

Strategic Pathways fails on all three counts.

* It is being introduced in a rush with minimal consultation.  It is not based on any form of cost-benefit analysis.

* It increases waste by centralizing administration wherever possible in ways that increase (not decrease) UA's overhead costs. 
      Having a single engineering, education etc. school doesn't actually reduce anything - it further entrenches the largely redundant Statewide Administration and creates an added layer of bureaucracy [e.g. "super deans" that are physically disconnected from 2 of the 3 institutions they serve].

* It reduces performance by reducing the ability of the various campuses to match their teaching and research programs to the needs of the communities they serve & by forcing faculty to spend hours dealing with "strategic pathways" generated busy work of no benefit to their campus or students.

Comment: Thanks for proving my point.  Take away the 34 miles of the already existing Seikan Tunnel and it's still only $80 million a mile, or 84% cheaper than Honolulu rail, IF it comes in at $10 billion.  Only about 10% of Japan's land is arable, and in a country the size of California that has 130 million people, that makes the available farm land very valuable.  

I traveled the route from Tokyo to Hakodate last year, and it definitely goes through valuable Hokkaido farm land, and I'd say that at least a quarter of it is in tunnels bored through mountains.  So I guess boring tunnels through mountains and laying seamless tracks capable of handling a 160 mph train is cheaper than laying conventional rails on defective plastic shims for our low speed driverless wonder in Honolulu?  Who would have thought?

Comment: Let's start here: "Inductive reasoning, from facts to theories..."  No.  Inductive reasoning does not begin with facts and argue to a theory, but with observations and the attempt to create diagnostic evidence from those that provide support for certain hypotheses (probable conclusions).  The conclusion follows from the initial argument's premises and supporting evidence but, always, with greater or lesser likelihood; inductive reasoning is, definitionally, uncertain.
At its most basic, NL is "Do good, avoid evil."  But "evil" has the broader philosophic definition of something that is against its nature.  Blindness is a physical "evil" in that it is against the nature of the eye (and related systems).  So NL is not premised, as some erroneously suppose, to be based on observations in the natural world and extract a moral conclusion from that, but upon the nature of an object itself and how that nature is actualized.

Comment: Allan:

Almost all environmental law boils down to one simple principle:

Clean up your own mess.

We teach that basic rule to every child in kindergarten.  It is what "polluter pay" is all about.

It is actually an embodiment of profound economics: an economy is always, always, always stronger when economic actors are forced to internalise their own negative externalities inside the price mechanism.

Not forcing internalisation of negative externalities is exactly equivalent to a subsidy - where the magnitude is uncapped, and is limited only by the appetite of the polluter. The entire economy bears the cost of the polluter's selfishness.

Eliminating that subsidy unburdens the economy.

It is often argued that only rich countries can afford environmental law.  That is exactly backwards.  If it were true, then economies with strong environmental law would be poorer, not richer.  Yet that is clearly not what the evidence shows.

Strong environmental law creates jobs and wealth.

Comment: THE DAY HE DIED

		For Lonny Kaneko

That morning I pruned
the red lace-leaf maple tree, 
branches bleeding sap

into a still-cold
soil, crows circling over
my head. Early light

spoke of promises
the earth has made forever,
that all will grow back

in time. I believed
only in impermanence,
the falling away,

loss, pain, struggle, death.
Crows laughed on incoming wind,
knowing the full truth.

Comment: Good gravy!

This is exactly what I mean by straw men.

There is no doubt that Christ is present where two or three are gathered.  This is due to the Priesthood of the Baptized.  This presence, however is distinct from other ways that Christ is present in the Church.  

The Sacraments are specific points of encounter with the ministry of Christ.  They put us into touch with one or more aspects of his ministry--in a concrete manner.  The Ministerial Priesthood is how God mediates the graces of the Sacraments to the people of God.  While Christ is present where two or three are gathered, the presence in the Sacraments is a specific type of presence that mediates specific types of graces.  

While we do not absolutely need the Sacraments to experience the presence of Christ, God desires to grant specific graces though the Sacraments.  We miss out on a more fuller and perfect encounter with Christ if we dismiss the Sacraments as superfluous.

Comment: McKenna makes no reference to this part of the Bank release: “The Bank’s three measures of core inflation, taken together, continue to point to material excess capacity in the economy.” Don’t know about that but they are suspiciously stable. On average they are unchanged at 1.6% in November, December and January, while the All-items CPI has gone from 1.2% to 1.5% to 2.1%, the old CPIX measure has gone from 1.5% to 1.6% to 1.7% and the previous operational guide CPIXFET has gone from 1.6% to 1.7% to 2.1%, above the 2% target rate. The Bank of Canada has obviously given up on fighting core inflation; instead it has moved the goalposts.

Comment: Absolutely no quibble with any of the arguments or figures put forth in this article.

But at the risk of sounding like a misogynist, there is one fact the author has overlooked.  Women of childbearing age are much more likely to take parental leave than men.  Some opt for a few more years of unpaid leave once the benefit runs out.

Many managers do not like to take the perceived risk of a key player being absent for one or more years.  It is somewhat discriminatory, but it is reality.  That perceived risk largely disappears once a woman is in her late 30s, but if she has been overlooked for promotion early in her career, she is at a disadvantage for climbing the corporate ladder.

Is it fair?  Of course not.  But it is reality.

Comment: And the accumulation of aluminum found in Alzheimer's patients may be related to a lack of B12, specifically methylcobalamin, given the impact on methylation in the body.

Methylation is important for doing a number of things including clearing toxins and heavy metals in the body and a deficiency in methylated compounds in the body (including B12) would result in accumulation of metals such as aluminum.   See a medical school biochemistry book for an explanation.

As they say, correlation isn't causation and just because aluminum is high in many Alzheimer's patients, it doesn't mean that the aluminum caused the condition.   Alzheimer is more likely caused by a combo of genetics and the impact of low B12 on metabolic processes in the body, with accumulation of metals (including aluminum in brain plaques) being a symptom, rather than a cause.

Comment: Federal-provincial negotiations over the last several months on a new Health Accord have triggered a series of opinion pieces in the Globe on how Canada's single-payer, universal health care system should be reformed.  Regrettably, not one of the articles, including this one, addressed the root cause of our failing system. Canada's health care system is costly, inefficient and delivers poor results to patients.  Ten European countries, including highly socialist Sweden, provide better and more efficient health care.  These countries allow the private sector to provide primary health care in direct competition with the private sector.  This competition improves outcomes for patients and lowers costs.  Canada needs to follow Europe's lead if health care costs are to be controlled while at the same time improving patient care.

Comment: Unfortunately, it's probably too late for Alberta. There's only one successful global model for how to create long-term prosperity by exploiting fossil fuels and Alberta has chosen not to adopt it. It's the Norwegian model of extracting the oil at a pace that doesn't warp the economy,  funding government programs through tax revenue, ensuring the state actually has a stake in projects, and using the resulting oil revenues to build a sovereign wealth fund. Instead, Alberta has embraced the North American model of doing everything possible to attract private companies to extract the oil as quickly as possible, and used the paltry royalties they have collected to fund their government. 

The result: Norway has over $1 trillion in their sovereign wealth fund ($235,000/person), and Alberta has $18 billion ($4,000). It will be tough for both economies as the world transitions away from fossil fuels. But it will be a disaster for Alberta. And an entirely predictable one.

Comment: I get that the median "should" have given the driver adequate room to regain control of the vehicle and avoid the crash.  For whatever reason, it didn't.  What WOULD have done the job is what most states install on busy interstates...a real barrier.  Either an ARMCO or Concrete retention barriers would have protected all the drivers, including the one who crossed the median.  Colorado is relatively cavalier about using guardrails...whether along steep slopes (ever been on the Million Dollar Highway?), drainage areas, or divided highways.  The cost of this one collision - in lives lost, medical bills for survivors, lost income and productivity, and the massive traffic delays and detours associated with investigation and cleanup - would pay for a LOT of ARMCO.  It's also important to note that MANY rollovers can be attributed to careening into a median in a high-CG vehicle like an SUV or truck.  ARMCO can prevent this.  CDOT didn't cause the accident, but they failed to prevent it.

Comment: Fossil fuels will continue to be used, and the economically reachable ones will be used up. It matters not whether that happens a little faster or a little slower. The experiment is well underway; we have already driven up the CO2 concentration by one third above pre-industrial levels. The evidence, so far, does not suggest that this has had a big effect on the climate. Temperatures have increased in a minor way (Don't confuse El-Nino events like those in 1998 and 2015/16 with CO2 effects.) Climate-related disasters have not increased in frequency or severity - no, comparing dollar amounts of damage is not the right metric.

The hard facts about "climate change" simply give no reason for panic, and not for economic self-mutilation either.

Comment: Yours is a populist argument that will never fly.  Here's why:

- Civil servants' voting rights are a Charter issue now; it should be held separate from any election reform movement,
- The AG is an appointed position.  If you're interested in a democracy, no appointed position should be allowed to wield legislative power; that is the domain of an elected lower House,
- Recall has precedence in judicial rulings that refute pre-election political promises becoming post-election obligations.  Also, remember that MP(P)s other than Independents are representatives of their Party.  If you recall an MP(P), you effectively recall the entire Party, which could trigger a general election.  There's probably some rule or ruling that constrains bringing down a Government to the will of Parliament, not the will of the Public.  To be otherwise is to support rule by the mob, be it Left or Right.

Comment: French immersion isn’t the boon most people seem to think it is.

My daughter has been in immersion since she was 4 and is now 13.  Her French grammar is shaky and her vocabulary is far from stellar.  I have noticed that most of her teachers have very poor English skills.

My son is in the English program because he struggled with French, and I have seen firsthand how underfunded it is.  Split classes are the norm, not the exception, and there is very little in the way of field trips or other enrichment.  

I question the value of French as a second language.  The de facto standard internationally is English, and even here at home, fluency in French outside of Quebec qualifies people for careers in only retail or the federal government.  Parents want French immersion because there is a perception that the quality of instruction will be better.  School boards should be working at improving English programs rather than expanding French immersion.

Comment: Might also mention Pierre Trudeau as an effective middle power leader.
.
I didn't think he was particularly good at it, which is why I didn't list him with Pearson (who was excellent), and St. Laurent (who was sublime).
.
Trudeau could, and did, irritate several of our allies, repeatedly - and his relationship with Nixon was the stuff of legend ("I've been called worse things by better people.")
.
But Gerald Ford liked Trudeau, which is why Canada was included in the G7.  Being included in the G7 is about as influential as any middle power can ever hope to be.  Canada has been at that table for 40 years.
.
So, in that way, Pierre Trudeau was ultimately quite successful.

Comment: "Was the British fire code completely inadequate or was it merely ignored? These are legitimate questions for urgent examination"

I have no idea about the requirements in Britain: my bet is that they're as sensible as those in Canada.

But I'm aware of situations where public safety requirements in Ontario are being ignored. The result is that Toronto could face a sudden inferno, the death toll of which could easily exceed that at Grenfell.

There are a dozen sites in Toronto and one in Kingston that I'm aware of. To take one example in Toronto, we have two highrises that are immediately next to the largest liquids pipeline in the province. The buildings are about 40 metres away from the pipeline. They are also downhill: any liquid fuel that's released will flow toward the buildings.

Each of these buildings is 22 storeys high with 370 units... almost certainly over 1,000 people in each. There are two more identical highrises further downhill: residents there would have a [TBC]

Comment: Smith still will receive his full pension, which was valued at $18.4 million 

Smith earned $15 million in total compensation just in 2016, including a $1.5-million base salary and $7.3 million in stock awards, according to the company’s securities filings.

Smith is scheduled to testify before the Energy and Commerce Committee Oct. 3 and a Senate Banking Committee hearing the next day.

Comment: Murder is murder. The proof of the illegal act is the fact the person is dead. Rape is different. Non-testimonial evidence of rape may  look the same as consensual sex. 6th amendment of the US constitution affirms the right of all persons to confront the witnesses against them. This is echoed article 1 section 11 of the Alaskan constitution, and requires the opportunity to  question the witness against them in open court. The confrontation right is generally only waived if the defendant did something to procure the unavailability of the witness, which does not appear to be the case here.  
So let us presume that the state takes the case to trial. Her statement to law enforcement that she was raped would not likely be admissible. If she had his DNA in her, this information would be admissible. However, all he would have to do is take the stand and say it was consensual. Thestate would have no way to rebut this testimony. It sucks. But it is the law, and DA's and courts are bound by it.

Comment: Dear Fr. Thomas,

Thank you for writing this article. Of course, the identity of the Church's priests is a very important thing: they are first and foremost servants of God. What I can't understand, then, is why sexual orientation need be an important aspect of that priestly identity: you seem to agree, insofar as a man should not be turned away from seminary based on sexual orientation.

At the same time, would the irrelevance of sexual orientation in selecting priests not also carry over into the active lives of the priests? It is perfectly irrelevant that a man is attracted sexually to this or that category of people when that man is a priest. Hence, there is no meaningful classification of "gay priests" or "straight priests", but only priests as such. What good is to announce one's "identity" as a "gay priest" if that is irrelevant to his duties as a servant of God? That only exacerbates issues through the prism of identity politics and needless sensation.

Comment: From the article: "raising questions about whether the decision to go into the red when times were good was foolish in retrospect"
=============

One does not need to wait to "retrospect" on this one, it is a BAD idea regardless of what economic philosophy one follows.

It is extremely rare that you can get all economists to agree on one thing, but if you were to say "Is it a good idea to run big deficits to stimulus an economy when you are at the peak of an economic cycle" you would get a nearly unanimous "NO!".  Even Keynes, who's name is used to justify deficit spending, was STRONGLY opposed to deficit spending during periods of economic strength.  His main contribution to economic thought was the notion of "counter-cyclical spending", ie government should spend during economic downturns and cut back during periods of economic strength.

Comment: As you note, when used as a term denoting sentimental disposition, "racist" is empty of significant moral importance. As a term describing material policies and actions, however, it is morally significant. I maintain that functionally, materially, we are all inescapably racist, without respect to our sentiments. Racism is essentially baked in. It is the historic and ongoing structure of material racial injustice that begs to be addressed, and the most pertinent sentiment, with respect to that project, is a will for justice, and a willingness both to acknowledge unjust privilege, and to put it on the table, so that the benefits of society may be more justly distributed. Our reluctance to do so is profoundly evident, across the political spectrum. It's the one thing on which most of us agree, some tacitly, and some vociferously.

Comment: Keep in mind Snarky that the NYT was building its premise on one Masters thesis and its associated research. There had been no time for peer review at the point the Times wrote the article. I don't have the time myself to explore intervening years to see if other scientists have since rejected the methodology and analysis mentioned in the paper.
I remember the hub-bub over non-peer reviewed analysis by a few scientists 40 years ago that was picked up by national magazines and reported as fact.That was in regard to the myth of global cooling, which was quickly debunked when the scientific community weighed in. That was the only time in my career I was rubbing elbows with atmospheric scientists at INSTAAR. They were quite upset at the way non-peer reviewed information was presented to the public so irresponsibly.

As for the NYT? Neither of us can claim to understand why editorial staff does or doesn't bother with various topics. Remember, its ultimately all about selling advertising!

Comment: There's something disturbing about a person who would find him acceptable.  When I hear their justifications, I get a sick feeling in my stomach. But I'm not at all surprised. This is us; they are us; this is humanity, and it's a problem. I've not believed that "people are good," or "most people are good," or "most people are basically good" for a long time. The field of psychology thinks it has a pretty good handle on the prevalence of personality disorders and mental illnesses, which addresses the prevalence of human beings without conscience, empathy, or a sense of responsibility. It's more than most people think.

The Milgram experiment is one of the scariest things I've ever looked at. It basically says that 66% of the general population will fatally electrocute a total stranger simply because another total stranger insists they do so. The victim can be screaming, begging, crying, but two out of three continue to torture. 

Some people are truly good. It's probably a bell curve.

Comment: The rules (or in this case the law) is being followed.

The RCMP are arresting and detaining them under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and turning them over to Canada Immigration for processing.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: Exactly.  This is known as the "free-rider problem" in economics.  It has been well demonstrated that  free common goods (in this case, health care which feels "free") leads to over consumption and under production.  Too much of this and the system implodes.

To protect the common good in question, governments need to mitigate the free-rider problem by a) some sort of user fee or co-pay or tax, and/or b) regulation/rules.

I'm an advocate for a careful implementation of a version of option (a).  Regulation/rules on how health care can be used and when it cannot is very undesirable, in my view.

Comment: Economics is a religion that pretends to be a science.  In science, knowledge starts with data drawn from reality.  This data (literally, what is "given") is then analyzed, and theories are extracted that attempt to explain the events that gave us the data.

In economics, the theories came first.  The goal seems to be to impose one or other of these theories on reality such that it creates the data which will show the theory to be valid.  But mainly, the goal seems to be to justify policy by invoking parts of economic theories as though they were already manifest.  "The market will do this or that..." and so we should have this or that policy.  

Never mind that such justifications are fantasies, with little or no rel data that supports these policies.  It is social engineering and prophesy pretending to be critical thought.  

E very time I hear some official person say something like "The market will determine wages," I can't help but feel like we are living in a monetary theocracy.

Comment: JJ, horses are not "mechanical transport," that's why they are allowed on trails in some Wilderness Areas.  And every time someone complains about horses in Wilderness Areas, I just shake my head. It is estimated that horseback riders are 10 times smaller than mountain bikers.  Mountain bikers are around 2.8% of the population where horseback riders are around .24% of the population.

And you write "9 times out of 10 this is about a user group (hikers) not wanting to share space, nothing more. It's a "we were here first" thing"   That's totally incorrect.  I'd say the thing hikers want is to hike in peace.  The amount of trails that are hiker only is dwindling every day.   The Forest Service says that mountain bikers can ride on 78% of their trails, that means hikers can only have peace on 22% of the trails.

Comment: While I have a high level of education, I am over 50 and in a low income bracket. Despite this, I do buy organic food whenever possible. Why? First, it is more ecologically sustainable and yes, healthier, as peer-reviewed literature does indicate (with many fewer harmful pesticide residues). Despite what some have written here, organic yields are, on average, nearly as good (95%) as what industrial agriculture yields and - in poorer nations - often higher. Organic soils sequester more carbon than those found on "conventional" farms. Furthermore, animals raised organic are more likely to live in situations that avoid cruelty. As someone who has actually published academic research in this area (in respectable, peer-reviewed journals), I make the choice to buy organic despite the cost. That being said, I think much more needs to be done to make organic food more easily available to low-income persons.

Comment: If the the public's expectation has been that Part 135 accidents would disappear because of the existence of the Medallion Foundation, then the public has been misled.  I know for a fact that the Medallion Foundation has never made such a claim.  

The Foundation has definitely claimed that it has improved aviation safety in the state of Alaska, and it is correct on that count.  Capstone and weather cams have also improved safety, as Mondor points out.  

The difficult truth is that no operator has an FAA inspector riding jump seat every flight, and no operator has a Medallion auditor sitting in their offices overseeing their Safety Management System every day.  Both types of oversight amount to periodic inspections and/or audits, and then the air carrier is left to their devices.

Comment: I'm pretty confident that I know one Helluva lot more about History generally and labor history specifically than you do, and consequently, I don't accept the Howard Zinn version of US History.   Somehow in the late-19th and early 20th Centuries American industrial workers attained the highest standard of living of any industrialized workers in the World.   Prior to the Civil War America was chronically short of skilled labor and it was very expensive; it was also significantly unionized.   From the War onward heavy immigration increased the labor supply and in low-skill work suppressed price of labor but the dramatic growth of US industry acted to increase the price of skilled labor.   It isn't businesses job to be a friend of labor, but it does need skills and somebody showing up, and it does what it takes to get that.   If you were an unskilled immigrant or a Southern agricultural worker, America was a tough go, but you could move up and most did.

Comment: Not all Evangelicals are Protestant. Catholics tend to use the word "Protestant" as a shorthand for "not Catholic or Orthodox" but technically it means members of the churches that were formed in the Reformation.

In general, Lutherans, Presbyterians and anything with the word Reformed in its name is Protestant. Methodists and Congregationalists, kind of. Mormons, Adventists, Christian Scientists and Pentacostals, not.

In Germany, "Evangelikalismus" just means, more or less, Lutheran. But in the US, "evangelical" is a pretty mushy word. All sorts of people call themselves "evangelical." Sometimes it just means "I like to talk about my religion."

Comment: Just to add some numbers to this...

For 2014/15 fiscal year the Federal government had total program expenditures of $254B.  For 2015/16 this had increased by 6.7% to $271B, some of which was due to changes that happened prior to the 2015 election, some of which happened after the election.  For 2016/17 the latest estimates show program expenditures of $288B, an 8.2% increase.  For 2017/18 the current expectation is another 5% or so increase.

All of this is well in excess of long-term nominal GDP growth, meaning each year a larger and larger proportion of our country's economy is made up of government spending.

Needless to say this is not sustainable over the long term. This is exactly the kind of thing that landed Canada in a dire fiscal situation following the massive increases in government spending in the late 1970's/early 1980's.  That time it took us nearly two decades to recover from out-of-control spendings, let's not repeat that mistake!

Comment: Lots of heat but little light on what 'appropriation' means.  To appropriate something isn't just to use it, but seems to involve denying something to someone else.  Suppose enterprising foreigners use a native folk design to sell clothes.  It's unfortunate if they put local craftspeople making more authentic products out of business.  It's also unfortunate when someone abuses and cheapens a real work of art to peddle stuff, because it can spoil everyone's enjoyment of the original.

But wait:  what if the  inauthentic items actually create interest and increase business for the locals?  Somebody has done them a favour!  What if the locals copyright designs their ancestors made?  Have they appropriated their own culture?  

Nobody owns folk songs and folk stories., so anybody can repeat them or use them to make something new.  Sometimes the result is an improvement.  If you don't like it, feel free to write your own music or story, or offer a more authentic version.

Comment: I will never forget how it felt to learn, in 2004, that citizenship had been stripped from my family with no notice, hearing or way to appeal.   That was for being the family of a WWII Veteran of the Royal Canadian Artillery and his War Bride: we were born in WWII Britain and arrived here to join our father  in 1946, as he had been discharged home to Ontario.

We did not lie,  did not commit fraud or any other criminal offence.   We all worked, farmed, served (my brother is a Navy veteran) and paid our taxes for over 50 years.  And we are just one example of one group of many across Canada who lost citizenship for a dozen ridiculous reasons.  
 
The decision to revoke, especially  with no judicial process,  should not be up to any one politician, bureaucrat or their designates. I hope all Lost Canadians like us will now get restoration and that this practice of revocation will  end for good.

Comment: The Canadian economy created 308,000 jobs in the last 12 months, according to Statistics Canada.  So if you bring in 340,000 immigrants per year you're already creating 32,000 unemployed immigrants, let alone Canadians who can't find work.

And where are these immigrants going? In Ontario they're going to Toronto.   The Fraser Institutes new study on Ontario points out: "Toronto and Ottawa CMAs alone created the equivalent of 98.6 percent of all new net jobs in Ontario between 2008 and 2016."  
https://www.fraserinstitute.org/tags/job-creation

So all these new immigrants are going to add to congestion in Toronto and drive housing prices even higher.  So most immigrants won't be able to afford a house or rent an apartment.

Finally, there is no "labour shortage" in Canada.  If there was a "labour shortage" then wages would increasing. And wages are not increasing.  In fact, wages raises are below the inflation rate.

There is no case for increased immigration.

Comment: "The author is quite correct in saying that the real economy decreases each time taxes are increased. Spending is the true problem not revenue."

You couldn't be more wrong.
.
If you were right, then we would all be on water wells and septic tanks, and we wouldn't have schools, police departments, or fire departments. 
.
Your foolish comment assumes that public sector spending has negative utility.
.
There s a recent OECD report: "Fiscal Balances and Public Indebtedness".  No text, just annual data back to 1999.  The numbers speak volumes.  Among other things, they show the disastrous effect of the Bush tax cuts, and the enormous ($160 Billion, to date) harm done by the GST cut.  The correlation between tax cuts and prosperity is very weak, and slightly negative.
.
Taxes are at a 60 year low.  They are not too high.  They are too low.
.
Canada's economy was substantially healthier when both spending, and especially taxes, were higher under Paul Martin.

Comment: For someone who works at UAF, it seems to me that the focus has always been Anchorage First. UAF has a renowned engineering department so the legislature provides funds to build an engineering building - at UAA. We get a shell. We have internationally acclaimed scientists at UAF and so UAA is allowed to create science programs that confer Masters and doctoral degrees, both of which were and are already available at UAF. Sixty-five percent of Alaskans live in southcentral and so most of the legislators are from southcentral. The legislature is largely to blame for the excessive money spent on duplication at UA. The idea behind Strategic Pathways, if I understand it correctly, is that each of the three MAUs will have a focus yet all will continue to offer the courses that are required as general education requirements. I agree that the faculty and public should have a significant role in affecting the decisions being made re. the university but I advise against holding your breath.

Comment: The television set these days for many people might just as well be called a Netflix set, since watching commercial television requires wasting one's leisure time watching commercials, over which there is no time limit. How then do Canadians get exposed to Canadian culture? The answer is they pay for it, but they don't receive it, as in, for example, subsidies to the CBC, and higher prices for services which are required to pay for content in French, English, and maybe Chinese for all we know. What has happened, of course, is the Internet combined with high speed downloading so that streaming video has become far more cost-effective than paying for cable tv. Advertising is now via the Internet for almost everybody, including online versions of our newspapers,

Comment: I've served on my condo board for 10 years; the condo law is actually fairly good at protecting owners. But a lot depends on the quality of the board, and the management company. When voting for board members, look for people with some expertise that will help when they're making decisions; some knowledge of finance, business, law - even knowing how to read a financial statement -- is important. And be wary of one-issue people, people with an agenda (i.e. getting rid of a particular manager or management company -- because once they do that they often look for other ways to cause trouble). When I meet newcomers in my condo I always introduce myself as a board member and encourage them to come to board meetings. Our board has worked with one of the largest management companies, where our agent had too many clients to respond to our needs in a timely manner. We hired a small company and are much happier.

Comment: > In Canada, women are paid less than men in 90 per cent of jobs tracked by Statistics Canada.

Of course a lot of people will accept this "throw away" statistic at face value. However 'Pay Equity' has been the law of the land since the 1980's (i.e. people doing the same job must be paid the same). 

So we're left with this puzzle then that companies must be some how or other skirting Pay Equity laws. So how do major companies, for instance, who typically have HR departments that spend a lot of their time looking into such things as job pay scales, do this? 

Or are there some other factors at work here? An inexplicable statistic, aside from supporting the reporter's personal biases, isn't of much use.

Comment: Income tax debate aside, it is true that there is tremendous waste in any business (or surely gov't) entity with more than a handful of workers. I used to work in corporate accounting, for a business with 350 employees.  Just in a small sliver of my own area of responsibility, I saved the company over $1 million per year, just by auditing the paperwork that people turned in.  Mistakes, intentional or not, add up to huge numbers.  Poor procedures allow tons of money to go down the tubes.  If the same auditing was done throughout that business, I can only imagine the savings.  There's no reason it wouldn't be the same for government.  Streamlining and auditing might not erase the need to increase revenues, but it would surely mitigate it.

Justice is not to be understood only as the due maintenance of a contractual agreement between equivalent parties. More to the heart of it, it is a virtue, the greatest of the virtues, by which living beings conduct themselves as far as they can according to what is best in their nature. Nonhuman animals are not by nature moral agents, so we do not expect a reciprocity from them as we would from fellow humans. But humans are most certainly moral agents, at their best seeking what is good. And usually our love of justice has included a sense that the weak and vulnerable deserve mercy and compassion from those who are stronger.

Comment: The board was correct in declining to hear public comment on a personal matter.

The matter is personal because the relationship is not explicitly forbidden by district policy. Maybe it should be, and that is a matter the public is entitled to weigh in on. In light of the current controversy, however, the board should receive those comments in writing and keep any deliberations on a potential policy change focused on the general case.

If the board changes the policy and an alleged romantic relationship continues in violation of that policy, then there may be a reason for complaint. Right now, there is not.

Even if all that weren't true, as neighbors and friends of some allegedly involved parties, the Hollomans are much too close to the situation to have any objectivity. They need to back off and let the board decide what is appropriate.

Comment: During the 1948 Arab-Israeli War, Jews living in the Jewish  Quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem were besieged and forced to leave en masse. Colonel Abdullah al-Tal, local commander of the Jordanian Arab Legion, described the destruction of the Jewish Quarter in his memoirs, (The Palestine Catastrophe: the Memoirs of Abdullah al-Tal, Leader of the Battle for Jerusalem, Cairo, 1959):

"... The operations of calculated destruction were set in motion.... I knew that the Jewish Quarter was densely populated with Jews who caused their fighters a good deal of interference and difficulty.... I embarked, therefore, on the shelling of the Quarter with mortars, creating harassment and destruction.... Only four days after our entry into Jerusalem the Jewish Quarter had become their graveyard. Death and destruction reigned over it.... As the dawn of Friday, May 28, 1948, was about to break, the Jewish Quarter emerged convulsed in a black cloud - a cloud of death and agony."

Comment: On Canadians living abroad being allowed to vote, that I one thing I do support.

Many Canadians may move abroad for perfectly legitimate reasons and have no intent to sever their ties with Canada.  For example, a former co-worker of mine moved to the United States for several years so she could complete her university degree.  Once she graduated, she came back to Canada.

The bigger issue, I think, is controlling the way some people come to Canada and live here just long enough to get Canadian citizenship, then go back to wherever it is they came from.  Their sole reason for having Canadian citizenship is to have an insurance policy to get them out of their mother country in the event the situation there deteriorates to the point things get dangerous.  And, being Canadian citizens, they can also demand the Canadian government help them out.

Comment: The_Nexus,

Thanks for the great! 

It's interesting, somewhat hopeful, but still (on balance) sad to realize that the circle of what constitutes "Old Stock" appears to enlarge over time but that the same sort of nativist and even xenophobic fears and anxieties continue (albeit directed by a broader band of peoples at other new peoples) in the same old way.

During a recession in the decade before WW I, the Scots of Calgary (of which my Grandfather was one) included many merchants that put NENA signs (No English Need Apply) in their shop windows as a not gentle reminder to recent English immigrants that (a) they wouldn't be hired, and (b) Scots were Calgary's top dogs.  In the wake of WW I, the KKK became a major political force in Saskatchewan amongst Protestants of British heritage who feared Eastern European immigrants.  An on and on as the circle of "Old Stock" grew, but its fear of newcomers kept reemerging during times of economic difficulty.

Comment: To the doom sayers out there and in this comments section: I was able to sell my detached Toronto house for a very good price a few weeks ago, with eight offers on the table, all delivered on the day we had reserved for offers. We also got a bully offer several days before the deadline, so that made nine offers in total.

We essentially got our "home run" scenario (about $300k over asking) albeit based on our reduced expectations following the March- decline.

That's totally anecdotal I admit, but it seems to me the market still has a bit of pop in it, even if it isn't in the nuclear territory we saw earlier in March. 

Anyway, now that we've withdrawn from the GTA to rent for a few years, I've no skin in this game anymore. But I have heard the doom predictions of a crash for more than a decade, and the Toronto market has proven quite resilient. We'll see....

Comment: If you face the same standards and expectations as everyone else, and find the job overwhelming, then you don't belong in that job.  Go find a better fit elsewhere.

Passing probation should not be the end goal.  While the bar for releasing an employee is lower for those on probation, it's still quite possible to release a non-probationary employee for poor performance.   Six months of "due process", done properly, and anyone could be released.  

I have seen poor performing employees play the mental health, discrimination and harassment cards in a last ditch effort to hold their jobs.  It almost never works, unless there is disclosure well in advance of the culminating incident.  The stress of the moment may be a mitigating factor, but it is not directive on its own.  

Both experts were correct that details of your departure must be kept confidential.  As the employer, I would simply confirm start and end dates, the role performed, and that the employee resigned.  No more.

Comment: "Military members disobey orders at their own risk. 

They also obey orders at their own risk. 

An order to commit a crime is unlawful. 

An order to perform a military duty, no matter how dangerous is lawful, as long as it doesn't involve the commission of a crime."

Articles 90, 91, and 92 of the UCMJ  

Ultimately, it's not whether or not the military member thinks the order is illegal or unlawful, it's whether military superiors (and courts) think the order was illegal or unlawful.

Manual for Courts Martial

"An order requiring the performance of a military duty or act may be inferred to be lawful and it is disobeyed at the peril of the subordinate. This inference does not apply to a patently illegal order, such as one that directs the commission of a crime."

Comment: The case for “current climate change is natural” is the theory that needs explaining.

Yes, there's a cycle. However, going back several hundreds of thousands of years, we see temperature swings of the glacial/interglacial cycles were a shockingly SLOWER order of magnitude than the warming rate we're currently experiencing.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2000_Year_Temperature_Comparison.png

In fact, outside of catastrophic geological events like the Paleocene Eocene Thermal Maximum (period of massive carbon injection into the atmosphere when the planet was essentially ice-free) there are no known precedents - natural or otherwise! - for warming this fast on a global scale.

If it is "natural," then how can you explain our high CO2 levels having no impact whatsoever? There's no climatological theory in which CO2 does not drive global temperatures. There's no logical or scientific theory in which humans are not producing CO2 by burning fossil fuels like coal, natural gas and oil.

Comment: I find Mr. Sinnot to be an educated, empathetic biologist who treats animals as humanely as possible, not the 'fear-mongering, biased, truth-denier' that this columnist portrays him to be. As the columnist admits, Sinnot is an 'experience wildlife biologist'. That's why I pay attention to his commentaries. He has a wealth of experience, and seeing him on the polar-opposite side of this columns' argument adds weight to his position, in my opinion. I love cats, and they are my preferred critter, bar none. Nothing like having a purring bundle of warm fur ensconced in your lap as you watch the news or read the paper. However, I have direct experience with feral cats and they are quite a nasty change of direction on your normal housecat. They have a direct, proven deleterious effect on small mammal and bird populations. If Ms. Robinson wishes to take all of Anchorage's feral cats to HER place, please do. But don't bring TNR -here-. Far more humane to put these poor critters down.

Comment: In terms of price, the GTA average is now $760,356. In April it was $919,589. That’s a drop of more than $159,000, or 17.31% in just a few months. The declines have been historic: down 6.2% in May, another 8.1% in June, and 4.2% in just the first two weeks of July.

By every definition, this is a sharp, deep and ferocious correction. If it were the stock market under discussion, we’d be just days away from an official bear market. That makes talk of a rebound in September kind of comical. Or irresponsible. Any buyer jumping in now to take advantage of a 17% price decline might end up losing all of their equity by the end of the year.

This will not end well...

Comment: If there is no budget by July 1, there is NO authorization to continue to operate State government, not even police, fire, jails, hospitals, the courts, many of the airports, the ferries, etc.   Somebody who knows State budget law better than I can answer whether a program with program receipts authority can expend program receipts without an authorizing appropriation.   A shutdown of State government isn't like the fake shutdowns of the federal government we've seen where the most vital things are kept running even without a budget.   The way the State is set up, there is NO authorization for anything at 12:01 AM on July 1.   On June 1, the Governor has to give every employee of at least the Executive Branch a layoff notice effective COB June 30.   I spent some interesting months of May and June in Juneau with no budget and no contracts; this one may be the most interesting ones ever.

Comment: The leftist political propaganda tells us that man-made greenhouse gases are causing an unnatural warming of the earth that will have devastating consequences for human life. Environmentalists and politicians are pressing for severe restrictions (taxes) on greenhouse gas emissions in order to prevent climate change. But what does the scientific evidence actually support regarding the causes of climate variability and the role of anthropogenic greenhouse gases? Are the predictions of catastrophic changes supported by scientific fact? Apparently not. Today’s CO2 concentration of around 385 ppm is very low compared to most of the earth’s history from ice core analysis - we actually live in a carbon-deficient atmosphere today. CO2 still constitutes only about 0.037% of the atmosphere and has no measured increase. The “Climate-gate” scandal revealed that a scientists and government agencies (NOAA in particular) had tampered with their own data so as to conceal inconsistencies and errors.

There are many reasons why the medieval development of the altar as wall with a tabernacle as its center piece was not fortuitous. 

The most important has to do with our conception of the Eucharist as PRIMARILY (1) sacred food and drink, or (2) an object of adoration. 

The essence of Eucharist in scripture is sacred food. Jesus confected the Eurcharist at the Last Supper at the dinner table, and commanded us to both eat and drink. For most of the first thousand years, our churches faithfully conveyed that original divine intent with an altar that was instantly recognizable as a dinner table, to which bread and wine were brought, and from with the body and blood of Christ was distributed as sacred food and drink in the form of bread and wine. The original scriptural word that was adopted for a church building was "ekklesia," which means "gathering" and which came to be understood as the "place of gathering." Its Jewish predecessor was the synagogue (essentially same meaning).

Comment: Australia is an interesting case. Smoking there has undeniably fallen lower than when they introduced PP, but there was already a long-term downward trend predating PP. Moreover their government hiked cigarette taxes several times since PP was enacted, muddying the waters.

Nevertheless researchers have gone to heroic lengths to argue that the policy worked. The Australian government's own report uses some rather dubious statistical models to show a downward effect on the smoking rate:
http://catallaxyfiles.com/2016/02/26/what-is-it-with-government-and-dodgy-regressions/

Meanwhile, other jurisdictions that never introduced PP — like the UK and Canada — also saw smoking fall over the same period, in some cases falling more steeply than in Australia. My guess is that if PP has any effect at all on smoking prevalence, it is greatly outweighed by other factors.

Comment: People agitated by the idea of 'thousands' of Syrian refugees I suspect are confusing 'refugee' with 'immigrant'.  These people are genuine refugees who Canada liberated from refugee camps in the Middle East (they're not migrants wandering into Europe who may or may not be refugees).   I think extending a hand to refugees is the proper humanitarian response from a country like Canada.

The real issue is the 300,000+ immigrants the Canadian government chooses to accept every year, the vast majority of course going to one of our 3 big cities.   We should call on our government to radically reduce these numbers, especially in a time of soft economic outlook, soaring housing prices, and the strain on the social and physical infrastructures of our cities.  Statistics now show that since the early 90s, instead of doing better, immigrants have been failing to succeed in Canada (this would be around the same time immigration numbers exploded).  We need honest dialogue about this not ideology.

Now realize that you live in the THIRD MOST EXPENSIVE CITY for health care in the United States (Fairbanks and Juneau are 1 and 2). ANYWHERE out of state is cheaper.  Insurance companies here will fly you and a friend to a center of excellence for a hip replacement or other surgery, put you in a nice hotel for the duration of recovery and bring you home and save 10's of thousands of dollars doing THAT, even though they've tried to bargain down the folks here.....
This is actually good news for EVERYBODY that needs a doctor in Anchorage.

If working women in some countries comprise mostly professionals, they will rank better compared to men.

So I wonder, why do we want to manipulate women's career choices?  Paid maternity leave is really irrelevant in determining career choice and thus a red herring.  Why do we want to steer women into high stress long hour jobs instead of letting individuals make their own choices?  Nanny state.

Comment: A very civil reply.  However, is there anyone today who thinks pidgin is low brow or vulgar?  If nothing else, our local comedians have put that notion to rest.  Pidgin can be used to communicate, to entertain, or just to prove one isn't a snob!  Those negative attitudes may have been prevalent in the past, but the children and grandchildren of those who created Hawaiian pidgin now preside over our courtrooms, practice medicine, own and manage our businesses, teach in our schools, and much more.  Their success depended upon their command of standard American English.  As a Hawaiian, I don't understand why some seek to impose the past on the present and future.  Pidgin served its purpose in a particular time and place.  Preserve it in print or use it if you wish but, with just so many hours in a school day, don't teach it.  Perhaps someone could do a study of Hawaii residents whose primary language is Hawaiian pidgin and its relation to career and financial success.

Comment: I had emergency surgery two and a half years ago for a ruptured abdominal abscess caused by a stage 3 colon tumour that had been missed by colonoscopy screening. Although it was very serious, it wasn't as serious as what the writer went through (while no one discussed whether or not I would recover from the surgery at the time, I'm on palliative chemo, so I am staring impending death in the face). Still, I recognize some of the things mentioned. An oncology nurse told me that she likes her job because cancer patients are some of the easiest patients to manage: they appreciate everything done for them and tend to forgive mistakes and just let things that would bother other patients roll off their backs. I think that serious illness makes many people realize how precious life is and that it is too short to be spent feeling angry about anything, or trying to change anyone.

Comment: G&A, People who feel they've become an unbearable burden to others may, and do, commit suicide without assistance. So the issue is inherent to a person's circumstances, not to assisted suicide itself. 

In one sense the new assisted suicide law is a protection for such people. They must ask their doctor for one, who is then in a position to offer resources to the patient.  The doctor will not grant an assisted suicide to someone simply because they feel they're a burden. They must (under the current rules) be close to death anyway. And under the SCC's criteria, they must have a grievous and irremediable medical condition that's causing them unbearable suffering. Neither of those rules contemplates giving an assisted suicide to someone on the grounds of being a burden to others.
