Comment: Great editorial.

It's a delusion to take the 2016 Brexit Referendum result as a set-in-stone fiat from 'the People' that the UK must leave the EU on any terms that can be achieved and in any economic and social conditions that might be unfolding and, in particular, that Parliament has no role save to support Brexit whatever that might mean.

First, no one (certainly not the leaders of the Brexit YES side) advocated a hard, come what may Brexit during the Referendum campaign.  In fact, those leaders proceeded to run for cover (i.e. avoid responsibility or office as UK Government leaders) once the unexpected and narrow pro-Brexit vote was known.

Over the ensuing months, the UK Government has been drifting zombie-like into a hard Brexit corner for want of a viable alternative.  If it wants a mandate to proceed down that path, it should call an election (which, in the absence of viable political opponents, it might well win). But, to argue that Parliament should but out is madness.

Comment: "Climate models are typically run with time steps of about 30 minutes. A climate model run for a century might, therefore, involve 1,753,152 (the number of half-hours in a century) time steps. All model parameters (temperature, wind speed, humidity, etc.) would be calculated at each of the thousands to millions of grid points in the model at each of those time steps. "
" Models use grids of "cells" to establish the locations of the "virtual weather stations." A typical climate model might have grid cells with a size of about 100 km (62 miles) on a side. The "virtual weather stations" are located at the corners of the grid cells."
"Early climate models typically had about 10 layers vertically; more recent ones often have about 30 layers"
"Vertical layers might be spaced at 11 km intervals "
That calculation/forecast  is performed at each 3D grid cell.
see: https://scied.ucar.edu/longcontent/climate-modeling

Money should be invested into developing future technology that works for our needs and not wasted on technologies that don't work just because we are panicking.

Comment: This is gonna sound controversial to some but, on the whole Castro's legacy was positive. I am looking at this from the perspective of someone from the Global South. 
(i)He assisted Nelson Mandela in the fight against Apartheid. 
(ii)In my country(Jamaica) he played a pivotal role in sending doctors and helping in land reform. 
(iii)He supported anti imperialist and anti colonial movements globally, but especially in Africa. 
(iv)Though he was an atheist, he supported Liberation theology in the 80s which included his relationship with Fr. Ernesto Cardenal in Nicuragua. 

He was authoritarian and I want Cuba to be a democracy. I am also critical of his treatment of Cuba's LGBT population and his suppression of dissidents. But I think on the whole the balance sheet shows more positives than negatives.

Comment: The basic principle that governed voting in colonial America was that voters should have a "stake in society." Leading colonists associated democracy with disorder and mob rule, and believed that the vote should be restricted to those who owned property or paid taxes. Only these people, in their view, were committed members of the community and were sufficiently independent to vote. Each of the thirteen colonies required voters either to own a certain amount of land or personal property, or to pay a specified amount in taxes. 

This rule was in effect for over 100 years. This country would be in a much better place if we had stuck to this system. Too many people are transient in this country, most home owners only stay 5-7 years and then move. They don't develop a sense of community with there neighbors and towns. People who live in Apartments or just rent don't pay there share of taxes but get the full benefit of other peoples money in services. Own land Vote, renters no vote.

Comment: It has occasionally happened in the past.  I can think, in particular, of situations like the Hibernia project off the coast of Newfoundland and Labrador that received substantial government "investment" in the 1980's/early 1990's and is still, to this day, partly owned by the Federal government.

There are more recent examples at the Provincial level in Newfoundland and I believe Saskatchewan has also made some direct subsidies in resource companies (potash in particular) if not necessarily oil and gas.

I can't think of any recent Federal direct contributions to companies.  There have been many oil and gas subsidies but those take the form of things like accelerated capital cost allowances.  Such subsidies also exist for manufacturing and are above and beyond this kind of direct investment.

Comment: Some of the "insights" may be misleading.  For example, talking about 2 stocks that each have a 65% probability of outperforming, the probability of both outperforming being 42%. This makes it sound superior to buy just 1 stock.  Now let's step into the real world, the stock you buy ends up going down 30% and the stock you don't buy doubles.  OOPS!  If however you split the position, you might still be ok.  If both stocks outperform by the same amount, you're no worse off than if you had bought only 1. And yes if you buy the stock that goes up and avoid the stock that goes down, clearly that's the better scenario but what are your odds of doing THAT?  Then of course there's the possibility both stocks go down, then you had better revisit your analysis and probabilities.

Comment: It has virtually nothing to do with protected classes. There are two separate issues here. And both have been addressed by the courts. One is the nature of the cake and/or its decorations, and the other is the nature of the customer(s). In the first one, the baker has the leverage: no one can compel him to create a swastika cake, a naked body (or body parts) cake, a cake decorated with hate speech, or anything else with a shape, flavor, or decorations that the baker finds objectionable. All within any limits imposed by the relevant laws and codes. 
.
That is not the issue at hand. 
.
This is: when you open a business offering specific goods and/or services to the public, your ability to refuse service to someone is rightly limited by the relevant laws. Phillips violated those laws. If he refused to sell such a cake to a couple of neo-Nazis, that would have been a violation as well.

Comment: Unable to agree on any particular method for selecting presidential electors, the Founding Fathers left the choice of method exclusively to the states in Article II, Section 1
“Each State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors….”  
The U.S. Supreme Court has repeatedly characterized the authority of the state legislatures over the manner of awarding their electoral votes as "plenary" and "exclusive." 
	
The current winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes is not in the U.S. Constitution. It was not debated at the Constitutional Convention. It is not mentioned in the Federalist Papers. 

The constitutional wording does not encourage, discourage, require, or prohibit the use of any particular method for awarding a state's electoral votes.

The bill retains the constitutionally mandated Electoral College and state control of elections, and uses the built-in method that the Constitution provides for states to make changes

Comment: Colorado’s Effort Against Teenage Pregnancies Is a Startling Success
https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/06/science/colorados-push-against-teenage-pregnancies-is-a-startling-success.html
The birthrate among teenagers across the state plunged by 40 percent from 2009 to 2013, while their rate of abortions fell by 42 percent, according to the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment. There was a similar decline in births for another group particularly vulnerable to unplanned pregnancies: unmarried women under 25 who have not finished high school.

“Our demographer came into my office with a chart and said, ‘Greta, look at this, we’ve never seen this before,’ ” said Greta Klingler, the family planning supervisor for the public health department. “The numbers were plummeting.”

The changes were particularly pronounced in the poorest areas of the state, places like Walsenburg, a small city in southern Colorado where jobs are scarce and many young women have unplanned pregnancies.

Comment: I couldn't help but think of the Syrian refugee issue when reading this article. We in Canada have been quite self-congratulatory and even smug about our willingness to take in a tiny fraction of those displaced by the Syrian civil war. Yet, our broader efforts to help the millions trapped in refugee camps who will never make it here or to another Western country pale in comparison. Essentially what we've done is promote a lottery where those who win are deemed worth of our empathy and support while those who lose or cannot or choose not to enter the lottery are left to their own devices. At the very least, it's an issue we should contemplate. If either the main objective and/or the principal outcome is to make us feel better about ourselves, particularly when we let countless other social inequities fester, is our approach virtuous or primarily self-serving?

Comment: The case you and Sean cite narrowly focused on specifically competing rights and in a divided decision the SCC  essentially held that the rights of an accused in a criminal trial can in some instances supersede religious rights. Many legal analysts view the decision as only the first round in what will be a longer and presumably broader debate. Also, the decision would appear to sustain my position that religious rights aren't absolute under the Charter. The Belgian example involves a more comprehensive debate about public policy intended to serve broader societal objectives conflicting with arguments favoring religious freedom. The European Court of Human Rights has (utterly reasonably, in my opinion) sided with the primacy of the former, a precedent that should influence decisions in other democratic jurisdictions.

Comment: The latest effort to fix health care with fairy dust comes from California, whose Senate voted last week to establish a statewide single-payer system. As ambitious as the California legislation is, encompassing everything from routine checkups to dental and nursing-home care, its authors haven’t yet figured out how it will be paid for. The plan includes no copays, premiums, or deductibles. Perhaps that’s because the legislature’s own estimates suggest it would cost at least $400 billion, more than the state’s entire present-day budget. In fairness, legislators hope to recoup about half that amount from the federal government and the elimination of existing state and local health programs. But even so, the plan would necessitate a $200 billion tax hike. One suggestion being bandied about is a 15 percent state payroll tax.
Of course, it is no surprise that Medicare for All would be so expensive, since our current Medicare program is running $58 trillion in the red going forward.

Comment: Until the point in time where the collectivists are successful in their goal of establishing a single national government to subjugate the people of this Union, there will never be a single national election held.  Why the low information voter crowd the Democrats so love to mislead still believe there is a single national election held for the presidency of the Union where every citizen of every State casts a vote defies any reasonable or logical explaination.  There are 51 separate elections conducted .  One in each State and one in the District of Columbia. Those elections are to select delegates from theStates and DC to cast votes in the presidential election, much like we hold elections in every State to select Senators who then cast votes for that State's population on legislation.  The selection of a president is a representative process, not a direct one.  It hasn't ever been a direct process and God willing never will be a direct process.

Comment: Here's another WWII story:

My father was probably saved by those bombs (as were many other Canadian soldiers).  Dad had orders from the Canadian Army in the summer of 1945 to go to the US to begin training on US equipment in preparation for the Invasion of Japan.  (Apparently all allied forces had agreed to only use US Army equipment for the invasion.) 

He was in the Royal Canadian Dragoons (Armoured Car Regiment).  They were to be part of the British Commonwealth Corps in Operation Coronet, the invasion of Honshu to take Tokyo.  The allies estimated that Operation Coronet would be a beach landing 3 - 4x larger than the Normandy Invasion. Just before they were to leave the US dropped those bombs and the war ended. 

As terrible as this poor women's experience was, millions of allies and Japanese were saved by the quick end to that war.

Comment: And, the provincial governments don't work together to leverage their collective purchasing power when sourcing medicines, equipment and so on.   For example, there are cancer drugs available and covered in some provinces that aren't even available in others.   Why is this?   Why are there such divergent views on the efficacy and value of one treatment versus another?   Why would Newfoundland, Alberta, Saskatchewan and Nova Scotia take one view, and the rest of the provinces another?   This kind of issue occurs a lot across the various health care systems in Canada, and it adds to the costs because of decreased purchasing power and economies of scale, among other issues.

Further, if the provinces ARE responsible for health care (as the repeatedly remind everyone again and again), why don't they grow up and show they can be responsible by sorting out their issues?   The want the (blank) cheques, but they are giving mixed messages about the rest.

Comment: The "cost" of coal always excludes black lung disease, coal mine explosions and deaths, coal ash heaps that burst into nearby rivers, slag piles and the tons and tons of pollutants that go up into the air.  Natural gas requires no miners, emits very little pollution by comparison and results in no slag or coal ash piles.  THAT is why coal is shutting down around the world.  Yes, there still is a market for high quality coal used in smelting but power generation is now relegated to being a backup - a good backup and a necessary (for now) backup - but not day to day generation.  BTW, gas fired plants are much easier to shut down and bring back up for demand bumps - not coal.

Comment: It's quite apparent that the author knows absolutely nothing about lake trout or catch and release fishing.  His attitude is typical for a commercial fisherman who thinks the only good fish is the dead fish in his pocket book.  If handled properly any fish can be released unharmed except some spawning salmon species.  Lake trout are a long lived fish that take 10-15 years to reach spawning size.  A 15 pound lake trout can be upwards of 25 years old and produce hundreds of thousands of eggs when they spawn every other or in some cases every few years.  Now I ask you if that happens to be the first fish you catch and you keep it how is that helping the resource?  I think the author is just trying to blame his lack of skill on someone else.  If Alaskans don't change their catch and kill mentality there will be no lake trout left.  There is always a risk of killing a fish when fishing that is just the nature of he beast but to say C&R kills every fish is just an ignorant comment.

Comment: They are testing intermediate range missiles -- "theatre missiles" -- not "ICBMs" or "Nukes".  They have the same right as any other nation to test their missiles over their territory and over international waters.  We do exactly the same when we test our ABMs out of Barking Sands against ICBM-like target missiles launched from Vandenburg.  

If NK tried to shoot down either of those missiles, Washington would deem it an extreme provocation "in America's own backyard" if not an outright act of war.  Why should NK be expected to respond any differently?  

We need to be very careful how we act here because Seoul is within range of perhaps 1,000 NK artillery pieces (not counting tactical missile batteries) that could inflict tens of thousands of casualties within a brief span of minutes -- more than that if they chose to use chemical munitions.  There's no effective defense possible against that initial assault.  Macho chest-thumping is a poor strategy in today's dangerous world.

Comment: One thing that happens at every hydro project that you only hear about decades later is the fact that landowners forced off their property never get lake from property that is eventually as good as gold. The developers always keep that for themselves to sell off years down the road. For example; a 1 acres lake front lot in the lower 48 sold for $6000 during the lake fill up period that took years and 40 years later sold for $450,000. The lake with 500 miles of shore line carries the local economy of the area to this day. Simply put, the value of the dam can not be measured simply in electrical costs. So when you look at the costs versus benefits, you have to look at both sides of the coin. If the dam is built; the displaced people should get a fair share of lake front as compensation in addition to what they get from eminent domain proceedings. And maybe free electricity for life or forever. You must also use the future value of the land for just compensation. Lake front is the $prize

Comment: Sue Careless gave the following commentary and advice to advocacy journalists, 
Acknowledge your perspective up front.
Be truthful, accurate, and credible. Don't spread propaganda, don't take quotes or facts out of context, "don't fabricate or falsify", and "don't judge or suppress vital facts or present half-truths"
Don't give your opponents equal time, but don't ignore them, either.
Explore arguments that challenge your perspective, and report embarrassing facts that support the opposition. Ask critical questions of people who agree with you.
Avoid slogans, ranting, and polemics. Instead, "articulate complex issues clearly and carefully."
Be fair and thorough.
Make use of neutral sources to establish facts.

Comment: Arguing that defense spending rates should be a certain level is like arguing other social spending - like for medical, pension, infrastructure, agriculture subsidies etc. should be at a certain level. If a country can do more with less and meet their obligations, international and domestic, then what is the problem? If on the other hand, a country is spending so much on defense that their obligations in other areas- domestic and internationally, cannot be met, how is that not a problem? I do not have all the answers but I do believe that viewed as a question of values and respect, peace might be better achieved by means other than intimidation, threats and obliteration. MAD has saved us from ourselves for 72 years but that does not mean that it will be a sustainable course forever.  Years ago we were supposed to get a peace dividend, it never happened and we again are facing escalating threats of violence as the arms race mutates and metastasizes. Maybe a plan B is called for.
